member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Container
member.summary: This section describes operations that you can perform on an AWS Elemental MediaStore container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Container.AccessLoggingEnabled
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AccessLoggingEnabled.
The state of access logging on the container. This value is false by default, indicating that AWS Elemental MediaStore does not send access logs to Amazon CloudWatch Logs. When you enable access logging on the container, MediaStore changes this value to true, indicating that the service delivers access logs for objects stored in that container to CloudWatch Logs.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Container.ARN
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ARN.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the container. The ARN has the following format:
arn:aws:<region>:<account that owns this container>:container/<name of container>
For example: arn:aws:mediastore:us-west-2:111122223333:container/movies

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Container.CreationTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreationTime.
Unix timestamp.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Container.Endpoint
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Endpoint.
The DNS endpoint of the container. Use the endpoint to identify the specific container when sending requests to the data plane. The service assigns this value when the container is created. Once the value has been assigned, it does not change.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Container.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Container.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
The status of container creation or deletion. The status is one of the following: CREATING, ACTIVE, or DELETING. While the service is creating the container, the status is CREATING. When the endpoint is available, the status changes to ACTIVE.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CorsRule
member.summary: A rule for a CORS policy. You can add up to 100 rules to a CORS policy. If more than one rule applies, the service uses the first applicable rule listed.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CorsRule.AllowedHeaders
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AllowedHeaders.
Specifies which headers are allowed in a preflight OPTIONS request through the Access-Control-Request-Headers header. Each header name that is specified in Access-Control-Request-Headers must have a corresponding entry in the rule. Only the headers that were requested are sent back.
This element can contain only one wildcard character (*).

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CorsRule.AllowedMethods
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AllowedMethods.
Identifies an HTTP method that the origin that is specified in the rule is allowed to execute.
Each CORS rule must contain at least one AllowedMethods and one AllowedOrigins element.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CorsRule.AllowedOrigins
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AllowedOrigins.
One or more response headers that you want users to be able to access from their applications (for example, from a JavaScript XMLHttpRequest object).
Each CORS rule must have at least one AllowedOrigins element. The string value can include only one wildcard character (*), for example, http://*.example.com. Additionally, you can specify only one wildcard character to allow cross-origin access for all origins.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CorsRule.ExposeHeaders
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExposeHeaders.
One or more headers in the response that you want users to be able to access from their applications (for example, from a JavaScript XMLHttpRequest object).
This element is optional for each rule.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CorsRule.MaxAgeSeconds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxAgeSeconds.
The time in seconds that your browser caches the preflight response for the specified resource.
A CORS rule can have only one MaxAgeSeconds element.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CreateContainerRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateContainer operation. Creates a storage container to hold objects. A container is similar to a bucket in the Amazon S3 service.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CreateContainerRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name for the container. The name must be from 1 to 255 characters. Container names must be unique to your AWS account within a specific region. As an example, you could create a container named movies in every region, as long as you donâ€™t have an existing container with that name.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CreateContainerRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
An array of key:value pairs that you define. These values can be anything that you want. Typically, the tag key represents a category (such as "environment") and the tag value represents a specific value within that category (such as "test," "development," or "production"). You can add up to 50 tags to each container. For more information about tagging, including naming and usage conventions, see Tagging Resources in MediaStore.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CreateContainerResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateContainer operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.CreateContainerResponse.Container
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Container.
ContainerARN: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the newly created container. The ARN has the following format: arn:aws:<region>:<account that owns this container>:container/<name of container>. For example: arn:aws:mediastore:us-west-2:111122223333:container/movies
ContainerName: The container name as specified in the request.
CreationTime: Unix time stamp.
Status: The status of container creation or deletion. The status is one of the following: CREATING, ACTIVE, or DELETING. While the service is creating the container, the status is CREATING. When an endpoint is available, the status changes to ACTIVE.
The return value does not include the container's endpoint. To make downstream requests, you must obtain this value by using DescribeContainer or ListContainers.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteContainerPolicyRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DeleteContainerPolicy operation. Deletes the access policy that is associated with the specified container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteContainerPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that holds the policy.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteContainerPolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteContainerPolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteContainerRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DeleteContainer operation. Deletes the specified container. Before you make a DeleteContainer request, delete any objects in the container or in any folders in the container. You can delete only empty containers.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteContainerRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container to delete.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteContainerResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteContainer operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteCorsPolicyRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DeleteCorsPolicy operation. Deletes the cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) configuration information that is set for the container.
To use this operation, you must have permission to perform the MediaStore:DeleteCorsPolicy action. The container owner has this permission by default and can grant this permission to others.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteCorsPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container to remove the policy from.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteCorsPolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteCorsPolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteLifecyclePolicyRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DeleteLifecyclePolicy operation. Removes an object lifecycle policy from a container. It takes up to 20 minutes for the change to take effect.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteLifecyclePolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that holds the object lifecycle policy.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteLifecyclePolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteLifecyclePolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteMetricPolicyRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DeleteMetricPolicy operation. Deletes the metric policy that is associated with the specified container. If there is no metric policy associated with the container, MediaStore doesn't send metrics to CloudWatch.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteMetricPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that is associated with the metric policy that you want to delete.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DeleteMetricPolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteMetricPolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DescribeContainerRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DescribeContainer operation. Retrieves the properties of the requested container. This request is commonly used to retrieve the endpoint of a container. An endpoint is a value assigned by the service when a new container is created. A container's endpoint does not change after it has been assigned. The DescribeContainer request returns a single Container object based on ContainerName. To return all Container objects that are associated with a specified AWS account, use ListContainers.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DescribeContainerRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container to query.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DescribeContainerResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DescribeContainer operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.DescribeContainerResponse.Container
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Container.
The name of the queried container.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetContainerPolicyRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the GetContainerPolicy operation. Retrieves the access policy for the specified container. For information about the data that is included in an access policy, see the AWS Identity and Access Management User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetContainerPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetContainerPolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetContainerPolicy operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetContainerPolicyResponse.Policy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Policy.
The contents of the access policy.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetCorsPolicyRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetCorsPolicy operation. Returns the cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) configuration information that is set for the container.
To use this operation, you must have permission to perform the MediaStore:GetCorsPolicy action. By default, the container owner has this permission and can grant it to others.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetCorsPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that the policy is assigned to.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetCorsPolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetCorsPolicy operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetCorsPolicyResponse.CorsPolicy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CorsPolicy.
The CORS policy assigned to the container.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetLifecyclePolicyRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the GetLifecyclePolicy operation. Retrieves the object lifecycle policy that is assigned to a container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetLifecyclePolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that the object lifecycle policy is assigned to.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetLifecyclePolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetLifecyclePolicy operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetLifecyclePolicyResponse.LifecyclePolicy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LifecyclePolicy.
The object lifecycle policy that is assigned to the container.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetMetricPolicyRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the GetMetricPolicy operation. Returns the metric policy for the specified container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetMetricPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that is associated with the metric policy.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetMetricPolicyResponse

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.GetMetricPolicyResponse.MetricPolicy

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListContainersRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the ListContainers operation. Lists the properties of all containers in AWS Elemental MediaStore.
You can query to receive all the containers in one response. Or you can include the MaxResults parameter to receive a limited number of containers in each response. In this case, the response includes a token. To get the next set of containers, send the command again, this time with the NextToken parameter (with the returned token as its value). The next set of responses appears, with a token if there are still more containers to receive.
See also DescribeContainer, which gets the properties of one container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListContainersRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
Enter the maximum number of containers in the response. Use from 1 to 255 characters.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListContainersRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
Only if you used MaxResults in the first command, enter the token (which was included in the previous response) to obtain the next set of containers. This token is included in a response only if there actually are more containers to list.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListContainersResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListContainers operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListContainersResponse.Containers
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Containers.
The names of the containers.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListContainersResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
NextToken is the token to use in the next call to ListContainers. This token is returned only if you included the MaxResults tag in the original command, and only if there are still containers to return.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListTagsForResourceRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListTagsForResource operation. Returns a list of the tags assigned to the specified container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListTagsForResourceRequest.Resource
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Resource.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the container.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListTagsForResourceResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListTagsForResource operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListTagsForResourceResponse.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
An array of key:value pairs that are assigned to the container.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.MetricPolicy
member.summary:
The metric policy that is associated with the container. A metric policy allows AWS Elemental MediaStore to send metrics to Amazon CloudWatch. In the policy, you must indicate whether you want MediaStore to send container-level metrics. You can also include rules to define groups of objects that you want MediaStore to send object-level metrics for.
To view examples of how to construct a metric policy for your use case, see Example Metric Policies.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.MetricPolicy.ContainerLevelMetrics
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerLevelMetrics.
A setting to enable or disable metrics at the container level.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.MetricPolicy.MetricPolicyRules
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MetricPolicyRules.
A parameter that holds an array of rules that enable metrics at the object level. This parameter is optional, but if you choose to include it, you must also include at least one rule. By default, you can include up to five rules. You can also request a quota increase to allow up to 300 rules per policy.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.MetricPolicyRule
member.summary: A setting that enables metrics at the object level. Each rule contains an object group and an object group name. If the policy includes the MetricPolicyRules parameter, you must include at least one rule. Each metric policy can include up to five rules by default. You can also request a quota increase to allow up to 300 rules per policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.MetricPolicyRule.ObjectGroup
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ObjectGroup.
A path or file name that defines which objects to include in the group. Wildcards (*) are acceptable.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.MetricPolicyRule.ObjectGroupName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ObjectGroupName.
A name that allows you to refer to the object group.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutContainerPolicyRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the PutContainerPolicy operation. Creates an access policy for the specified container to restrict the users and clients that can access it. For information about the data that is included in an access policy, see the AWS Identity and Access Management User Guide.
For this release of the REST API, you can create only one policy for a container. If you enter PutContainerPolicy twice, the second command modifies the existing policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutContainerPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutContainerPolicyRequest.Policy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Policy.
The contents of the policy, which includes the following:
One Version tag
One Statement tag that contains the standard tags for the policy.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutContainerPolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the PutContainerPolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutCorsPolicyRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the PutCorsPolicy operation. Sets the cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) configuration on a container so that the container can service cross-origin requests. For example, you might want to enable a request whose origin is http://www.example.com to access your AWS Elemental MediaStore container at my.example.container.com by using the browser's XMLHttpRequest capability.
To enable CORS on a container, you attach a CORS policy to the container. In the CORS policy, you configure rules that identify origins and the HTTP methods that can be executed on your container. The policy can contain up to 398,000 characters. You can add up to 100 rules to a CORS policy. If more than one rule applies, the service uses the first applicable rule listed.
To learn more about CORS, see Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) in AWS Elemental MediaStore.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutCorsPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that you want to assign the CORS policy to.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutCorsPolicyRequest.CorsPolicy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CorsPolicy.
The CORS policy to apply to the container.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutCorsPolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the PutCorsPolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutLifecyclePolicyRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the PutLifecyclePolicy operation. Writes an object lifecycle policy to a container. If the container already has an object lifecycle policy, the service replaces the existing policy with the new policy. It takes up to 20 minutes for the change to take effect.
For information about how to construct an object lifecycle policy, see Components of an Object Lifecycle Policy.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutLifecyclePolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that you want to assign the object lifecycle policy to.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutLifecyclePolicyRequest.LifecyclePolicy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LifecyclePolicy.
The object lifecycle policy to apply to the container.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutLifecyclePolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the PutLifecyclePolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutMetricPolicyRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the PutMetricPolicy operation. The metric policy that you want to add to the container. A metric policy allows AWS Elemental MediaStore to send metrics to Amazon CloudWatch. It takes up to 20 minutes for the new policy to take effect.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutMetricPolicyRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that you want to add the metric policy to.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutMetricPolicyRequest.MetricPolicy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MetricPolicy.
The metric policy that you want to associate with the container. In the policy, you must indicate whether you want MediaStore to send container-level metrics. You can also include up to five rules to define groups of objects that you want MediaStore to send object-level metrics for. If you include rules in the policy, construct each rule with both of the following:
An object group that defines which objects to include in the group. The definition can be a path or a file name, but it can't have more than 900 characters. Valid characters are: a-z, A-Z, 0-9, _ (underscore), = (equal), : (colon), . (period), - (hyphen), ~ (tilde), / (forward slash), and * (asterisk). Wildcards (*) are acceptable.
An object group name that allows you to refer to the object group. The name can't have more than 30 characters. Valid characters are: a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and _ (underscore).

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutMetricPolicyResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the PutMetricPolicy operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.StartAccessLoggingRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the StartAccessLogging operation. Starts access logging on the specified container. When you enable access logging on a container, MediaStore delivers access logs for objects stored in that container to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.StartAccessLoggingRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that you want to start access logging on.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.StartAccessLoggingResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the StartAccessLogging operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.StopAccessLoggingRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the StopAccessLogging operation. Stops access logging on the specified container. When you stop access logging on a container, MediaStore stops sending access logs to Amazon CloudWatch Logs. These access logs are not saved and are not retrievable.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.StopAccessLoggingRequest.ContainerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContainerName.
The name of the container that you want to stop access logging on.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.StopAccessLoggingResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the StopAccessLogging operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Tag
member.summary: A collection of tags associated with a container. Each tag consists of a key:value pair, which can be anything you define. Typically, the tag key represents a category (such as "environment") and the tag value represents a specific value within that category (such as "test," "development," or "production"). You can add up to 50 tags to each container. For more information about tagging, including naming and usage conventions, see Tagging Resources in MediaStore.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Tag.Key
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Key.
Part of the key:value pair that defines a tag. You can use a tag key to describe a category of information, such as "customer." Tag keys are case-sensitive.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.Tag.Value
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Value.
Part of the key:value pair that defines a tag. You can use a tag value to describe a specific value within a category, such as "companyA" or "companyB." Tag values are case-sensitive.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.TagResourceRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the TagResource operation. Adds tags to the specified AWS Elemental MediaStore container. Tags are key:value pairs that you can associate with AWS resources. For example, the tag key might be "customer" and the tag value might be "companyA." You can specify one or more tags to add to each container. You can add up to 50 tags to each container. For more information about tagging, including naming and usage conventions, see Tagging Resources in MediaStore.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.TagResourceRequest.Resource
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Resource.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.TagResourceRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
An array of key:value pairs that you want to add to the container. You need to specify only the tags that you want to add or update. For example, suppose a container already has two tags (customer:CompanyA and priority:High). You want to change the priority tag and also add a third tag (type:Contract). For TagResource, you specify the following tags: priority:Medium, type:Contract. The result is that your container has three tags: customer:CompanyA, priority:Medium, and type:Contract.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.TagResourceResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the TagResource operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.UntagResourceRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the UntagResource operation. Removes tags from the specified container. You can specify one or more tags to remove.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.UntagResourceRequest.Resource
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Resource.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the container.

member.name: P:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.UntagResourceRequest.TagKeys
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TagKeys.
A comma-separated list of keys for tags that you want to remove from the container. For example, if your container has two tags (customer:CompanyA and priority:High) and you want to remove one of the tags (priority:High), you specify the key for the tag that you want to remove (priority).

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.Model.UntagResourceResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the UntagResource operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.MediaStore.AmazonMediaStoreClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing MediaStore
An AWS Elemental MediaStore container is a namespace that holds folders and objects. You use a container endpoint to create, read, and delete objects.

member.name: M:Amazon.MediaStore.AmazonMediaStoreClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonMediaStoreClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.summary: Retrieves the properties of the requested container. This request is commonly used to retrieve the endpoint of a container. An endpoint is a value assigned by the service when a new container is created. A container's endpoint does not change after it has been assigned. The DescribeContainer request returns a single Container object based on ContainerName. To return all Container objects that are associated with a specified AWS account, use ListContainers.

member.name: M:Amazon.MediaStore.AmazonMediaStoreClient.ListContainers(Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListContainersRequest)
member.summary:
Lists the properties of all containers in AWS Elemental MediaStore.
You can query to receive all the containers in one response. Or you can include the MaxResults parameter to receive a limited number of containers in each response. In this case, the response includes a token. To get the next set of containers, send the command again, this time with the NextToken parameter (with the returned token as its value). The next set of responses appears, with a token if there are still more containers to receive.
See also DescribeContainer, which gets the properties of one container.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the ListContainers service method.
member.returns: The response from the ListContainers service method, as returned by MediaStore.
member.exception: The service is temporarily unavailable.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for ListContainers Operation

member.summary:

member.name: M:Amazon.MediaStore.AmazonMediaStoreClient.PutCorsPolicy(Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutCorsPolicyRequest)
member.summary:
Sets the cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) configuration on a container so that the container can service cross-origin requests. For example, you might want to enable a request whose origin is http://www.example.com to access your AWS Elemental MediaStore container at my.example.container.com by using the browser's XMLHttpRequest capability.
To enable CORS on a container, you attach a CORS policy to the container. In the CORS policy, you configure rules that identify origins and the HTTP methods that can be executed on your container. The policy can contain up to 398,000 characters. You can add up to 100 rules to a CORS policy. If more than one rule applies, the service uses the first applicable rule listed.
To learn more about CORS, see Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) in AWS Elemental MediaStore.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the PutCorsPolicy service method.
member.returns: The response from the PutCorsPolicy service method, as returned by MediaStore.
member.exception: The container that you specified in the request already exists or is being updated.
The container that you specified in the request does not exist.
The service is temporarily unavailable.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for PutCorsPolicy Operation

member.summary:
Sets the cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) configuration on a container so that the container can service cross-origin requests. For example, you might want to enable a request whose origin is http://www.example.com to access your AWS Elemental MediaStore container at my.example.container.com by using the browser's XMLHttpRequest capability.
To enable CORS on a container, you attach a CORS policy to the container. In the CORS policy, you configure rules that identify origins and the HTTP methods that can be executed on your container. The policy can contain up to 398,000 characters. You can add up to 100 rules to a CORS policy. If more than one rule applies, the service uses the first applicable rule listed.
To learn more about CORS, see Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) in AWS Elemental MediaStore.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the PutCorsPolicy service method.
A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the PutCorsPolicy service method, as returned by MediaStore.
member.exception: The container that you specified in the request already exists or is being updated.
The container that you specified in the request does not exist.
The service is temporarily unavailable.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for PutCorsPolicy Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.MediaStore.AmazonMediaStoreClient.PutLifecyclePolicy(Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutLifecyclePolicyRequest)
member.summary:
Writes an object lifecycle policy to a container. If the container already has an object lifecycle policy, the service replaces the existing policy with the new policy. It takes up to 20 minutes for the change to take effect.
For information about how to construct an object lifecycle policy, see Components of an Object Lifecycle Policy.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the PutLifecyclePolicy service method.

member.name: M:Amazon.MediaStore.IAmazonMediaStore.ListContainers(Amazon.MediaStore.Model.ListContainersRequest)
member.summary:
Lists the properties of all containers in AWS Elemental MediaStore.
You can query to receive all the containers in one response. Or you can include the MaxResults parameter to receive a limited number of containers in each response. In this case, the response includes a token. To get the next set of containers, send the command again, this time with the NextToken parameter (with the returned token as its value). The next set of responses appears, with a token if there are still more containers to receive.
See also DescribeContainer, which gets the properties of one container.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the ListContainers service method.
member.returns: The response from the ListContainers service method, as returned by MediaStore.
member.exception: The service is temporarily unavailable.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for ListContainers Operation

member.summary:
Creates an access policy for the specified container to restrict the users and clients that can access it. For information about the data that is included in an access policy, see the AWS Identity and Access Management User Guide.
For this release of the REST API, you can create only one policy for a container. If you enter PutContainerPolicy twice, the second command modifies the existing policy.

member.name: M:Amazon.MediaStore.IAmazonMediaStore.PutCorsPolicy(Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutCorsPolicyRequest)
member.summary:
Sets the cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) configuration on a container so that the container can service cross-origin requests. For example, you might want to enable a request whose origin is http://www.example.com to access your AWS Elemental MediaStore container at my.example.container.com by using the browser's XMLHttpRequest capability.
To enable CORS on a container, you attach a CORS policy to the container. In the CORS policy, you configure rules that identify origins and the HTTP methods that can be executed on your container. The policy can contain up to 398,000 characters. You can add up to 100 rules to a CORS policy. If more than one rule applies, the service uses the first applicable rule listed.
To learn more about CORS, see Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) in AWS Elemental MediaStore.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the PutCorsPolicy service method.
member.returns: The response from the PutCorsPolicy service method, as returned by MediaStore.
member.exception: The container that you specified in the request already exists or is being updated.
The container that you specified in the request does not exist.
The service is temporarily unavailable.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for PutCorsPolicy Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.MediaStore.IAmazonMediaStore.PutLifecyclePolicy(Amazon.MediaStore.Model.PutLifecyclePolicyRequest)
member.summary:
Writes an object lifecycle policy to a container. If the container already has an object lifecycle policy, the service replaces the existing policy with the new policy. It takes up to 20 minutes for the change to take effect.
For information about how to construct an object lifecycle policy, see Components of an Object Lifecycle Policy.

member.name: M:Amazon.MediaStore.IAmazonMediaStore.TagResource(Amazon.MediaStore.Model.TagResourceRequest)
member.summary: Adds tags to the specified AWS Elemental MediaStore container. Tags are key:value pairs that you can associate with AWS resources. For example, the tag key might be "customer" and the tag value might be "companyA." You can specify one or more tags to add to each container. You can add up to 50 tags to each container. For more information about tagging, including naming and usage conventions, see Tagging Resources in MediaStore.
